results.title: Tales from a suitcase: the Afghan experience [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, Look Television Productions, Will Davies and Andrea Dal Bosco
results.brief_description: This acclaimed SBS series takes the viewer through the experiences of Afghan people who came to Australia from the 1970s to the present. Seven diverse stories reflect the range of trials faced by people who have experienced life under numerous regimes, including Communism, Mujaheddin and the Taliban. Episode 1: Artist George Gittoes discuses his visit to Afghanistan, the stories of which inspired new work that speaks of harrowing tales. Episode 2: Professor Hala and Doctor Safi were once teacher and student at the University of Kabul. Their lives of politics, journalism and brutal persecution took them on separate courses until they both found asylum in Australia. Episode 3: In 1979 Abdullah Shariat left fourth year medical school to become a freedom fighter, in Northern Afghanistan, against the Communists. Episode 4: Karima Haroon is an exuberant young woman from Afghanistan who arrived in Australia as a boat refugee. Tragic circumstances have forced her to take responsibility for her entire family. Episode 5: Khadern Nori and Shafiq Monis are both from the Hazara tribe in Afghanistan. Following persecution by the Taliban they spent a treacherous journey aboard a boat travelling to Australia before spending a year in Woomera Detention Centre. Episode 6: Sayd Sarshar, a musician, Dr Nooria Mehraby, a counsellor, and Mohammed Arif, a refugee, discuss their country’s many years of turmoil. Episode 7: Abeda Iqbal and Massooda Hassan are two close girlfriends in their early twenties who arrived in Australia as children. They discuss their hopes for the future. Some quite remarkable and heart-rending tales emerge from these intimate and revelatory interviews.

results.title: Tales from a suitcase 4
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, Look Television Productions, Will Davies, Andrea Dal Bosco and David S. Vadiveloo
results.brief_description: This acclaimed SBS series presents the stories behind migration to Australia during the 1950s when many people fled post-War atrocities, the rise of Communism and impoverishment. This tape contains four separate stories. Episode 10: Chris Gatz was indoctrinated into Communism at a young age, embracing the doctrines that destroyed his family. In 1956 he immigrated to Australia to be re-united with his remaining family. Episode 11: Leopoldine Mimovich learnt sculpture in her home city of Salzburg, Austria. Arriving in Australia in 1949, she found living as a female artist a demanding calling. Episode 12: Nicolas Habib, born in Egypt to a Greek mother and Lebanese father, was a foreigner in his own homeland. Upon becoming effectively stateless, he moved to Australia where his lack of English saw his skills denigrated, forcing him to adapt to a life of hard labour. Nicolas recognised the many inequities faced by migrants of certain ethnic backgrounds, and agitated for change. Episode 13: Denis George immigrated to Australia at age 35 whereupon he became a pioneering pearl farmer. Some quite remarkable tales emerge about these interesting times, told with finesse by various raconteurs and are an appealing mix of pathos and humour.

results.title: Tales from a suitcase 3
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, Look Television Productions, Will Davies, Andrea Dal Bosco and David S. Vadiveloo
results.brief_description: This acclaimed SBS series presents the stories behind migration to Australia during the 1950s when many people fled post-War atrocities, the rise of Communism and impoverishment. This tape contains three separate stories. Episode 7: Jutta Malnic, born in Berlin to an Australian mother and German father, had a childhood filled with exotic stories about a country which provided refuge after harrowing World War II experiences. A photographer, Jutta relays her remarkable journey from war-torn Europe and her interesting experiences as an emigre. Episode 8: Victor Vadiveloo was taken from his family in Sri Lanka at age 4 and sent to work on the Burmese railway at 14, before escaping. Upon emigrating to Australia Victor continued his studies in order to become a surgeon, and experienced excessive racism which only intensified when he fell in love and married a white woman. Episode 9: Rinaldo Fabbro, an Italian partisan fighter during World War II who was to become an architect of great acclaim, discusses his past, having arrived in Australia in 1949, in search of prosperity. Some quite remarkable tales emerge about these interesting times, told with finesse by various raconteurs and are an appealing mix of pathos and humour.

results.title: Tales from a suitcase 2
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, Look Television Productions, Will Davies, Peter Hegedus and Veronica Iacono
results.brief_description: This acclaimed SBS series presents the stories behind migration to Australia during the 1950s when many people fled post-War atrocities, the rise of Communism and impoverishment. This tape contains three separate stories. Episode 4: Henry Sue fled China with his family when it became Communist. Once here, Henry battled racism and discrimination, which made him determined to fight back. Episode 5: Sasha Nekvapil and Frank Prihoda. Sasha defected from the Czech skiing team whilst competing in 1948 in Switzerland. She later emigrated to Australia with her husband and brother in search of new beginnings. Episode 6: Frank Buzolic was a black marketeer during World War II who lived on his wits whilst evading danger. At the conclusion of the war he and his brother sought freedom - they escaped escaping in a stolen dinghy, rowing toward Italy. Some quite remarkable tales emerge about these interesting times, told with finesse by various raconteurs and are an appealing mix of pathos and humour.

results.title: Tales from a suitcase 1
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, Look Television Productions, Will Davies, Andrea Dal Bosco and Debra Beattie-Burnett
results.brief_description: This acclaimed SBS series presents the stories behind migration to Australia during the 1950s when many people fled post-War atrocities, the rise of Communism and impoverishment. This tape contains three separate stories. Episode 1: Restaurateurs Beppi and Giuseppe de Carlo both came to Australia from Italy in the early 1950s founding restaurants that maintained the principles of Italian cooking. In interview and utilising stills and archival footage, these pioneering individuals discuss their past and the challenges faced introducing new ingredients and flavours, many of which were scarce and largely unheard of at that time. Episode 2: Rona and Krys Pawlowski both lost their families as a result of Hitler’s invasion of Poland during World War II. Ron became a partisan at age 14 and Krys was sent to Siberia as a schoolgirl, surviving innumerable hardships. This intriguing couple discuss their incredible history hunting crocodiles and selling the skins whilst raising children in remote and inhospitable areas of Australia. Episode 3: Hideko Coombes was born into a very strict, respectable family in Kure, Japan. At the end of WWII she married an Australian soldier and was one of 300 war brides that came to Australia in the 1950s. In a revealing interview Hideko discusses the resistance of her family, and his, to this couple’s union. Some quite remarkable tales emerge about these interesting times, told with finesse by various raconteurs and are an appealing mix of pathos and humour.

In interview and utilising stills and archival footage, these pioneering individuals discuss their past and the challenges faced introducing new ingredients and flavours, many of which were scarce and largely unheard of at that time. Episode 2: Rona and Krys Pawlowski both lost their families as a result of Hitler’s invasion of Poland during World War II. Ron became a partisan at age 14 and Krys was sent to Siberia as a schoolgirl, surviving innumerable hardships. This intriguing couple discuss their incredible history hunting crocodiles and selling the skins whilst raising children in remote and inhospitable areas of Australia. Episode 3: Hideko Coombes was born into a very strict, respectable family in Kure, Japan. At the end of WWII she married an Australian soldier and was one of 300 war brides that came to Australia in the 1950s. In a revealing interview Hideko discusses the resistance of her family, and his, to this couple’s union. Some quite remarkable tales emerge about these interesting times, told with finesse by various raconteurs and are an appealing mix of pathos and humour.
